symptoms: Brown diamond-shaped or oval lesions with gray centers
Spots merge and cause leaves to dry out
Lesions may appear on leaves, stems, and panicles
There are brown spots on the rice leaves that are white in the center
The leaves are drying from the tip
I see small brown patches on the leaves that are getting bigger
The leaves look burnt or damaged
There are round marks on the leaves that are spreading
The leaves have cut-like marks and are turning yellow
After rain, more spots are showing on the plants
The top part of the leaf is dry but the bottom is still green
Some stems also have brown spots now
Leaves have white patches in the middle and brown borders
There are long brown marks on the leaves turning white in the middle
The spots have white centers and dark edges
Leaves break easily where the spots are
Some leaves have holes where the brown marks were
causes: Fungal infection caused by Magnaporthe oryzae, thrives in high humidity and warm temperatures (25-28°C)
treatment: Apply Tricyclazole fungicide at 0.6g per liter. Spray twice: at tillering and booting stage. Alternative: Carbendazim or Edifenphos
prevention: Use resistant varieties like IR64, avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer, maintain proper plant spacing, remove infected debris, ensure good drainage
risk_season: Monsoon season and periods of high humidity (>85%)
symptom_questions: Do you see diamond or spindle-shaped spots on leaves?
Are the spots brown with gray centers?
Have the lesions spread to the stem or neck area?
Are young leaves more affected than old ones?
contextual_followups: Has there been heavy rainfall or high humidity recently?
Did you apply nitrogen fertilizer heavily?
Is this happening during the flowering stage?
Are your plants closely spaced?

symptoms: Lesions on leaf sheaths near water line
Oval to irregular lesions on sheaths
Greenish-gray lesions with brown margins
Water-soaked lesions on lower sheaths
White fungal growth in humid conditions
Lesions spreading upward from water level
The lower part of the plant near the water is turning brown and soft
There are wet patches on the leaf stems close to the ground
The stems have brown lines and spots that are spreading upward
The plants are falling down because the base is getting weak
The disease starts from the bottom and moves up slowly
It looks like the plant is rotting from the bottom
greenish-grey spots on leaf sheaths near water level
causes: Fungal infection by Rhizoctonia solani, favored by dense planting, high nitrogen, and standing water
treatment: Apply Validamycin at 2ml per liter or Hexaconazole. Spray at early tillering and again 15 days later. Drain water temporarily during treatment
prevention: Maintain proper plant spacing (20x15 cm), avoid excessive nitrogen, drain fields periodically, use silicon fertilizers to strengthen cell walls
risk_season: Peak tillering to heading stage, especially in humid conditions
related_pests: None directly, but water management issues worsen disease
symptom_questions: Do you see oval lesions starting from the water line?
Are the lesions greenish-gray with brown edges?
Do you notice white fungal growth in the morning?
Are your plants densely planted?
contextual_followups: Is water standing continuously in your field?
Did you apply high amounts of nitrogen fertilizer?
What is your plant spacing?
Have you seen this disease before in this field?

symptoms: Orange-red pustules on wheat leaves
Rust-colored spots on leaf surface
Reddish-brown powdery spots on leaves
Orange pustules breaking through leaf surface
Rust-colored powder on wheat leaves
Pustules on stems and leaf sheaths
causes: Fungal infection by Puccinia species (P. triticina for leaf rust, P. striiformis for stripe rust, P. graminis for stem rust). Spreads rapidly in moderate temperatures
treatment: Apply Propiconazole at 0.1% or Tebuconazole at 0.1%. For severe cases, use Mancozeb + Metalaxyl. Spray at flag leaf emergence and repeat after 15 days
prevention: Use resistant varieties (HD 2967, PBW 550), practice crop rotation, remove volunteer wheat plants, timely sowing to avoid peak rust season
risk_season: Late winter to spring (February-March), temperatures 15-25°C with dew
symptom_questions: Are the pustules orange-red or yellowish-orange?
Do you see rust-colored powder on your hands after touching leaves?
Are the pustules arranged in lines or scattered randomly?
Have you noticed pustules on the stem as well?
contextual_followups: Did you notice dew formation in the morning?
What variety of wheat are you growing?
Have neighboring fields been affected?
When did you sow this crop?

symptoms: White powdery coating on leaves
White dusty patches on wheat leaves
Flour-like white coating on leaves
White fungal growth on leaf surface
Yellowing of affected leaves
Premature leaf senescence
causes: Fungal infection by Blumeria graminis f. sp. tritici. Thrives in cool, humid conditions with poor air circulation
treatment: Apply Sulfur fungicide at 2g per liter or Triadimefon at 0.1%. Alternatively, use Hexaconazole. Spray at disease onset and repeat after 10-15 days
prevention: Avoid overcrowding plants, use resistant varieties, avoid excessive nitrogen, ensure good air circulation, timely removal of infected plants
risk_season: Late winter (January-February) with high humidity and moderate temperatures (15-22°C)
symptom_questions: Do you see white powder that rubs off easily?
Are the lower leaves more affected?
Is the coating on both sides of leaves?
Have you noticed yellowing of affected areas?
contextual_followups: Is your field in a shaded or poorly ventilated area?
Did you plant wheat very densely?
Has the weather been cool and humid?
Have you used high nitrogen fertilizers?

symptoms: Brown lesions on wheat leaves
Elongated brown spots on leaves
Tan to brown lesions with dark borders
Brown blotches spreading on leaves
Leaf tips turning brown and dying
Premature drying of leaves
causes: Fungal infection by Bipolaris sorokiniana (spot blotch) or Alternaria triticina. Common in warm, humid conditions and stressed plants
treatment: Apply Copper fungicide (Copper oxychloride at 3g per liter) or Mancozeb. For severe cases, use Propiconazole. Spray at tillering and booting stage
prevention: Practice crop rotation with non-cereals, use healthy seeds, avoid water logging, maintain balanced nutrition, remove crop residues after harvest
risk_season: Late season (grain filling stage), warm and humid conditions
related_pests: None directly, but heat stress worsens symptoms
symptom_questions: Are the lesions elongated with dark margins?
Do you see the disease starting from lower leaves?
Are the leaf tips dying back?
Has the disease reached the grain heads?
contextual_followups: What was your previous crop in this field?
Is the field well-drained?
Have temperatures been high recently?
Did you face water stress during grain filling?

symptoms: Dark scabby lesions on apple leaves
Olive-green to black spots on leaves
Velvety dark spots on apple leaves
Black sooty spots on leaf surface
Dark circular lesions on leaves
Cracked and deformed fruits
causes: Fungal infection by Venturia inaequalis. Overwinters in fallen leaves, spreads via rain splash in spring
treatment: Apply Captan fungicide at 2g per liter or Mancozeb. For organic: use Sulfur or Copper-based fungicides. Begin at green tip stage, repeat every 7-14 days
prevention: Remove and destroy fallen leaves in fall, use resistant varieties (Liberty, Enterprise), prune for good air circulation, avoid overhead irrigation
risk_season: Spring (April-June) during wet weather, primary infection from overwintered spores
related_pests: None directly, but wounds from insects can allow entry
symptom_questions: Do you see olive-green or black velvety spots?
Are both leaves and fruits affected?
Did the spots appear after rain?
Are the fruits cracked or deformed?
contextual_followups: Did you remove fallen leaves last autumn?
Has there been frequent rain in spring?
What apple variety are you growing?
Do you use overhead sprinklers?

symptoms: Blackened wilted shoots and leaves
Burnt appearance of apple branches
Blackened leaves that stay attached
Shepherd's crook bending of shoots
Oozing cankers on branches
Sudden wilting during bloom
causes: Bacterial infection by Erwinia amylovora. Enters through blossoms, spreads rapidly in warm, humid weather. Highly contagious
treatment: Apply Streptomycin spray during bloom (200 ppm). Prune infected branches 12 inches below symptoms. Disinfect tools with 10% bleach between cuts. Apply Copper spray during dormancy
prevention: Prune infected branches immediately, avoid excessive nitrogen, use resistant rootstocks, plant resistant varieties (Liberty, Enterprise), remove infected trees if severe
risk_season: Spring during flowering, warm weather (18-30°C) with rain or high humidity
related_pests: Bees and insects can spread bacteria during pollination
symptom_questions: Do the shoots look burnt or blackened?
Are the branch tips curled like a shepherd's crook?
Did you notice sudden wilting during or after flowering?
Is there sticky ooze on the branches?
contextual_followups: Did the symptoms appear during or after bloom?
Was there rain or hail during flowering?
Have you seen this in your orchard before?
How quickly did the symptoms spread?

symptoms: White powdery coating on apple leaves
Silvery-white patches on leaves
White fungal growth on leaf surface
Dusty white coating on apple leaves
Leaf curling and distortion
Stunted shoot growth
causes: Fungal infection by Podosphaera leucotricha. Overwinters in buds, emerges in spring, favored by moderate temperatures and low humidity
treatment: Apply Myclobutanil at 0.04% or Sulfur at 0.2%. For organic: use Potassium bicarbonate. Spray at pink bud stage and repeat every 10-14 days until petal fall
prevention: Prune infected shoots in winter, improve air circulation, use resistant varieties, avoid excessive nitrogen, remove diseased terminal buds
risk_season: Spring to early summer, moderate temperatures (20-25°C), low humidity paradoxically favors it
symptom_questions: Do you see white powdery coating on new growth?
Are the leaves curled or distorted?
Is the white coating on both sides of leaves?
Are the shoots stunted or rosette-like?
contextual_followups: Did you notice this on last season's terminal growth?
Is your orchard well-pruned with good air flow?
Have temperatures been moderate (not too hot)?
Did you remove infected shoots during winter pruning?

symptoms: Dark spots with concentric rings on leaves
Target-like lesions on tomato leaves
Brown spots with yellow halos on leaves
Circular brown lesions on lower leaves
Bull's eye pattern spots on leaves
Leaf yellowing and defoliation
causes: Fungal infection by Alternaria solani. Survives in crop debris, spreads via rain splash, favored by warm humid weather
treatment: Apply Chlorothalonil at 2g per liter or Mancozeb. Alternatively, use Azoxystrobin. Spray at first sign of disease, repeat every 7-10 days. Remove severely infected leaves
prevention: Remove infected plant debris, practice crop rotation (3-4 years), avoid overhead irrigation, mulch to prevent soil splash, stake plants for air circulation, use resistant varieties
risk_season: Throughout growing season, especially after fruit set, warm days with humid nights
related_pests: Flea beetles can create entry points
symptom_questions: Do you see target-like or bull's eye patterns on leaves?
Did the disease start on lower leaves?
Are the spots dark brown with yellow halos?
Have leaves started falling off?
contextual_followups: Did you practice crop rotation?
Is there old tomato debris in or near the field?
Do you water from overhead or at soil level?
Has the weather been warm and humid?

symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on tomato leaves
Dark green water-soaked spots on leaves
Brown lesions with white fuzzy growth
Rapidly spreading brown patches on leaves
Brown firm spots on fruits
Entire plant collapse in severe cases
causes: Oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans (same as potato late blight). Spreads rapidly via wind and rain, highly destructive
treatment: Apply Metalaxyl + Mancozeb or Cymoxanil + Mancozeb at first sign. Spray every 5-7 days. In severe cases, destroy infected plants. Apply Copper as preventive
prevention: Avoid overhead watering, ensure good air circulation, use resistant varieties, destroy volunteer plants, separate from potato crops, apply preventive fungicides in high-risk periods
severity_level: Very High - Can destroy entire crop quickly
risk_season: Cool moist weather (15-20°C), high humidity, especially during monsoon
related_pests: None, but can co-occur with aphids
symptom_questions: Are there water-soaked spots on leaves?
Do you see white fuzzy mold on undersides of leaves?
Are brown spots appearing on fruits?
Did the disease spread very rapidly?
contextual_followups: Has the weather been cool and moist recently?
Are there potato plants nearby?
Did you notice this after rain or heavy dew?
How fast did the symptoms spread?

symptoms: Sudden wilting of tomato plants
Yellowing and wilting of leaves
Brown vascular streaking in stems
Plant collapse without leaf yellowing
White bacterial ooze from cut stems
One-sided wilting of plants
causes: Bacterial infection by Ralstonia solanacearum. Soilborne, enters through roots, blocks water transport, very difficult to control
treatment: No effective chemical treatment. Remove and destroy infected plants immediately (burn or bag, don't compost). Soil solarization in off-season. Treat soil with biocontrol agents like Pseudomonas
prevention: Use disease-free transplants, practice long crop rotation (4+ years), improve drainage, avoid wounding roots, use grafted plants on resistant rootstocks, soil amendment with organic matter
severity_level: Very High - No cure once infected
risk_season: Warm weather (25-35°C), high soil moisture, year-round in tropical areas
symptom_questions: Did the plant wilt suddenly on a hot day?
If you cut the stem, do you see brown streaks inside?
Is there white ooze coming from the cut stem?
Did the wilting start from one side of the plant?
contextual_followups: Have you grown tomatoes in this soil before?
Is the field well-drained or waterlogged?
Have you seen this disease in previous seasons?
Are there root-knot nematodes in your soil?

symptoms: Circular brown spots with concentric rings on leaves
Target-like dark spots spreading on potato leaves
Brown lesions with alternating light and dark rings
Bull's eye lesions on potato foliage
Dark brown spots with yellow borders
Collar rot at soil line
causes: Fungal infection by Alternaria solani. Overwinters in soil and debris, spreads via rain splash, favored by warm weather with alternating wet and dry periods
treatment: Apply Mancozeb fungicide at 2g per liter or Chlorothalonil. Spray at first appearance, repeat every 7-10 days. For severe cases, use Azoxystrobin or Difenoconazole
prevention: Remove infected plant debris, practice crop rotation, use certified seed potatoes, avoid overhead irrigation, hill up soil around plants, maintain proper plant nutrition
risk_season: Throughout growing season, peaks when plants are stressed or after flowering
related_pests: Colorado potato beetle damage can worsen disease
symptom_questions: Do you see target-like or concentric ring patterns?
Did symptoms start on lower, older leaves?
Are there dark spots with yellow halos?
Is there stem rot near the soil line?
contextual_followups: Did you plant certified seed potatoes?
Have you practiced crop rotation?
Is there old potato debris in the field?
Have temperatures been warm with occasional rain?

symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on potato leaves
Dark brown lesions with white mold on undersides
Rapidly spreading brown patches on leaves
Black rot on potato tubers
Entire field turning brown quickly
White fungal growth in humid conditions
causes: Oomycete Phytophthora infestans (same as tomato late blight). Spreads explosively via wind-blown spores, can destroy fields in days
treatment: Apply Metalaxyl + Mancozeb or Cymoxanil + Mancozeb immediately. Spray every 5-7 days. Use Copper fungicides as preventive. In severe outbreak, destroy crop to prevent spread
prevention: Use certified disease-free seed, plant resistant varieties, apply preventive fungicides before disease appears, destroy volunteer plants, ensure good drainage, forecast-based spraying
risk_season: Cool moist weather (10-20°C), high humidity (>90%), especially monsoon season
related_pests: None, but aphids may be present
symptom_questions: Are there water-soaked dark spots on leaves?
Do you see white mold on leaf undersides in morning?
Did the disease appear after cool, moist weather?
Are tubers showing brown to black rot?
contextual_followups: Has there been rain or heavy fog recently?
Are temperatures cool (below 20°C)?
Have neighboring fields been affected?
Did you use certified seed potatoes?

symptoms: Rough corky lesions on potato skin
Raised brown scabby patches on tubers
Cork-like rough spots on potato surface
Warty growths on potato tubers
Shallow to deep pitted scabs
Only tuber skin affected, flesh normal
causes: Caused by Streptomyces bacteria (S. scabies). Favored by alkaline soil pH (>5.5), low soil moisture during tuber formation, and warm temperatures
treatment: No direct treatment once infected. Focus on prevention. Avoid using infected tubers for seed. Scabby potatoes are safe to eat but unmarketable
prevention: Maintain soil pH below 5.2 using sulfur amendments, ensure adequate irrigation during tuber formation (critical 2-6 weeks after flowering), use resistant varieties, avoid fresh manure, practice crop rotation with non-susceptible crops
severity_level: Low to Medium - Cosmetic, doesn't affect eating quality
risk_season: During tuber formation, warm dry soil conditions
symptom_questions: Are the lesions only on the skin surface?
Do the scabs feel rough and corky?
Is the inside of the potato normal?
Did you notice this after harvest?
contextual_followups: What is the pH of your soil?
Did you water adequately during tuber formation?
Did you apply fresh manure before planting?
Have you grown potatoes here before with scab?
